Award.AwardTitle: TUES:Type1:Collaborative: An Integrative Hands-on Approach to Security Education for Undergraduate Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Security of information, software, and hardware has emerged as a paramount concern. Existing undergraduate curricula often do not provide students with adequate insight into the full spectrum of security threats and respective protection approaches. To fill this gap in the curriculum, this project is developing an interdisciplinary undergraduate course incorporating hands-on learning of computer security. The course provides a comprehensive system-level view of computer security to students, so they can become more aware of diverse security issues and countermeasures as future developers and users of computer systems. A distinctive aspect of the project is the inclusion of a set of well-crafted experiments that would allow students to hack into software and hardware in many creative ways. These experiments can be highly effective in demonstrating the complex nature of system security and creating an understanding of the defense mechanisms. The exposure to security issues early in their career can provide undergraduate students with a competitive edge in the market place and stimulate their interests in security research. The course modules can also benefit graduate students pursuing research in the area of computer security, as well as the K-12 students attending summer camps each year. The project provides a unique opportunity for exposing minority and female students in Cleveland State University to the critical issues of security and attracting them to higher education and research. The project uses the trust-hub web portal for disseminating the course modules to other academic institutions in a timely manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the primary objective was to develop a junior level course on hands-on learning of computer security at system level. It aimed at integrating coverage of important topics on software as well as hardware security into one course in order to provide undergraduate students a comprehensive, unfragmented system level view of security through well-designed hardware and software experiments.

The PIs and graduate students supported by this grant have worked together for past three years to successfully meet all the major milestones of the project. The collaboration between the two participating universities (initially between Case Western Reserve University and Cleveland State University and then between University of Florida and Cleveland State University after PI Bhunia moved to University of Florida) has been very fruitful. The PIs at Cleveland State University have focused on developing materials on software security and cryptography, while PI Bhunia has focused on developing materials on hardware security. The major outcomes and achievements of the project are listed below.

1. The most important result of the project is development of a well-designed set of course modules – in particular, the hands-on experiments on different aspects of hardware and software security for learning computer security issues at system level and their corresponding countermeasures through effective collaboration between two universities. In particular, PI Bhunia and the graduate student working with him in this project has successfully designed six hands-on experiments to help undergraduate students learn different aspects of hardware security encompassing all levels of hardware abstraction - from microchip to printed circuit boards to system hardware. The experiments allow students to learn innards of a computer system and its operation and understand its diverse security vulnerabilities. They also help them learn different types of countermeasures that can be employed to protect a system against these attacks. We have observed that the hands-on experiment greatly excite their creative interest and encourage them to learn the subject in greater depth. We have continually improved the experiments based on the student’s feedback during first two years’ (Fall 2015 and Fall 2016) offering.

2. The course is now being regularly offered in three universities: Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland State University, and University of Florida. In the first two universities, the course has been already offered three times during the three year period of the project (2014, 2015, and 2016). In the University of Florida, the course has been introduced in Fall 2016 after PI Bhunia moved here in Fall 2015. In all three universities, it has been a very popular course for the students based on students’ feedback. Overall, the course has already made positive impact to large number of undergraduate students (over hundred) and is poised to impact many more students.

3. We have already made the course modules available to greater community through our hardware security group webpage in Facebook, which currently has over 400 members including number of faculties and students as well as industry professionals all across the globe. We have also uploaded the course modules to popular web portal TrustHub (https://www.trust-hub.org/) for broader dissemination of the modules. Several universities (e.g. Florida Institute of Technology and University of Central Florida) have already contacted the PIs for adopting the course for their undergraduate students. The PIs are helping them to establish the course in their respective institutions.

4. Another significant outcome of the project is training a set of graduate and undergraduate students in the participating universities who have collaborated among themselves and have experienced the principles of working in a team. They have designed the individual experiments for the course and the process has stimulated their creativity. The students have constantly interacted among themselves as well as with the PIs to evaluate and gradually improve each experiment design. They have also obtained feedback from students enrolled in the class and incorporated them into the experiment design. They have also been involved as teaching assistant (TA) for the course and directly interacted with large number of undergraduate students from the class. Such teaching and mentoring experience has been very valuable for them.

5. We have developed a custom hardware platform for training students on different security issues and protection approaches. The specific hardware platform is designed by graduate students working in this project. It consists of many key components common to modern computing systems. It has many features that allow the user to implement a wide range of computer systems, and to conduct various hardware hacking experiments.

6. Additionally, the proposed curriculum development effort has also contributed to hardware security research activities, in particular: (1) analysis of hardware Trojan attacks in Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGA); (2) design of efficient security primitives, namely physical unclonable functions (PUFs); and (3) analysis of security issues in the hardware or software of the emerging internet of things (IoT) devices.
